data: The inscription runs on the upper edge of the tile.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.

Dall’alfabetizzazione alla permeabilità selettiva. Per una proposta di lettura della documentazione epigrafica del Mendolito

Valentina Mignosa, ‘Dall’alfabetizzazione Alla Permeabilità Selettiva. Per Una Proposta Di Lettura Della Documentazione Epigrafica Del Mendolito’, Incontri Di Filologia Classica 17 (2018 2017): 215–42
Le iscrizioni anelleniche del Museo di Adrano
Luciano Agostiniani, «Le iscrizioni anelleniche del Museo di Adrano», in Tra Etna e Simeto. La ricerca archeologica ad Adrano e nel suo territorio (Catania, 2009), 115–18
Luigi Bernabò Brea, il Museo di Adrano e gli inizi degli scavi al Mendolito

Paola Pelagatti, «Luigi Bernabò Brea, il Museo di Adrano e gli inizi degli scavi al Mendolito», in Tra Etna e Simeto. La ricerca archeologica ad Adrano e nel suo territorio (Catania: Biblioteca della Provincia Regionale di Catania, 2009), 16–26

Massimo Cultraro, «Funzione e destinazione delle tegole con iscrizioni anelleniche: nuovi e vecchi dati dal Mendolito di Adrano (Catania)», Studi Etruschi 70, fasc. 3 (2005): 227–51

Sulle tracce della lingua dei Siculi
F. Ribezzo, «Sulle tracce della lingua dei Siculi», Rivista Indo-Greco-Italica di filologia - lingua - antichità 7 (1923): 223–26

1δοͱιτ ιμ Ρυκες ͱαζσυιε[ς]

1dohit im rukes hazsuie[s]

1ΔΟͰΙΤΙΜΡΥΚΕΣͰΑΖΣΥΙΕ[.]

1DOHITIMRUKESHAZSUIE[.]

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Manganaro 1961

English translation

Valentina Mignosa

Gives this Ruke Hazsuie / Gift of Ruke Hazsuie.

Italian translation

Valentina Mignosa

Dà questo Ruke Hazsuie / Dono di Ruke Hazsuie.

commentary

The inscription has been interpreted by all editors as 'gift of' + an onomastic formula. It is on a fragment of a tile found in contrada Mendolito together with another one apparently written by the same hand. The two documents were initially interpreted as two funerary inscriptions (Manganaro 1961b, 110), then as a single votive inscription dedicated by magistrates to deities (Pisani 1964, 127; Whatmough 1968, 576-577; Ribezzo 1923, 224) and, more recently (Cultraro 2005), as a single inscription on the roofing slabs of a building (a house, or more likely a 'public' building) that would bear the dedication of a member of the community financing the structure. Whether these are parts of the same inscription is, however, difficult to prove due to the lack of specific details on the archaeological context and a connection - if not palaeographic - between this inscription and the other one that bears another (and different) onomastic formula (maybe the name of another donor). The alphabet is the typical one of Sikel inscriptions from the Etna area. Worthy of note, in particular, is the presence of the arrow-shaped alpha, the digamma (with value of v, see also ISic003364).

δοͱιτ ιμ Ρυκες ͱαζσυιες
dohit im rukes hazsuies
Text after Manganaro 1961

Gives this Ruke Hazsuie / Gift of Ruke Hazsuie.

Dà questo Ruke Hazsuie / Dono di Ruke Hazsuie.

The inscription has been interpreted by all editors as 'gift of' + an onomastic formula. It is on a fragment of a tile found in contrada Mendolito together with another one apparently written by the same hand. The two documents were initially interpreted as two funerary inscriptions (Manganaro 1961b, 110), then as a single votive inscription dedicated by magistrates to deities (Pisani 1964, 127; Whatmough 1968, 576-577; Ribezzo 1923, 224) and, more recently (Cultraro 2005), as a single inscription on the roofing slabs of a building (a house, or more likely a 'public' building) that would bear the dedication of a member of the community financing the structure. Whether these are parts of the same inscription is, however, difficult to prove due to the lack of specific details on the archaeological context and a connection - if not palaeographic - between this inscription and the other one that bears another (and different) onomastic formula (maybe the name of another donor). The alphabet is the typical one of Sikel inscriptions from the Etna area. Worthy of note, in particular, is the presence of the arrow-shaped alpha, the digamma (with value of v, see also ISic003364).
